title: 107_s241
content: The "National Election Standards Act of 2001" establishes uniform national standards for federal election procedures under Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Commission is required to establish national standards for federal elections to minimize delays, errors, and fraud, increase accuracy in vote counts, reduce uncounted ballots, encourage voter registration and turnout, ensure accessibility to polling places, and promote public confidence in the election process. Standards include ballot types, vote counting, and use of counting machines. The Commission is tasked with establishing national standards for federal elections, including ballot types, vote counting, use of counting machines, accuracy and security of elections, voter registration, and maintenance of voter rolls. The Commission will study and review State election regulations regularly and enforce standards under section 309(e) only. Regulations to carry out these provisions must be promulgated by January 1, 2002, based on an initial study of election procedures in each State. The Commission is responsible for setting national standards for federal elections, including procedures for ballot types, vote counting, and voter registration. States must comply with these standards within a specified timeframe, with the option to request waivers or extensions. The Attorney General can enforce compliance through civil penalties under section 309(e) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Attorney General can take legal action in district court to enforce requirements under section 323 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Additionally, criminal penalties are added to Chapter 29 of title 18, United States Code. It is illegal to conduct a Federal election in violation of national standards set by the Federal Election Commission. Violators may face fines or up to 3 years in prison. The Federal Election Commission can provide grants to States for implementing national election standards. States can use the funds for compliance with these standards by submitting an application to the Commission. The Federal Election Commission will approve applications for grants according to set standards and regulations. The Commission will issue regulations outlining the application process, content, grant amounts, and approval criteria. $100,000,000 is authorized for appropriations each fiscal year starting in 2002. The Federal Election Commission approved $100,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2011 for this subsection. The funds will remain available until expended. The Commission must submit reports to Congress on the activities under this subsection. SEC. 3 amends the election date to the first consecutive Saturday and Sunday prior to the first Monday. SEC. 4 addresses voter registration in federal elections. SEC. 4 amends the National Voter Registration Act to require states to allow same-day voter registration at polling places during federal elections.
